timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure about this one...
The client iterates over read only vectors. So he probably doesn't expect their value to change. Each next() call however, changes the value of the previously returned vector, since it's always the same instance being returned.
Therefore I think it would be cleaner to return new instance every time. (see next comment)
timeline.author: kBlaszczyk

replies.bodyText: I think the point is to reduce GC by avoiding creating a new instance. @skaldarnar how much does this matter with regards to performance and would it be better to make a new instance?
replies.author: pollend

replies.bodyText:
I just realized, that it even points this out in the javadoc: The iterating vector is reused.
So it was definitely done consciously. The GC argument is valid (even though we are having tons of unnecessary vector allocations at runtime anyway), so I guess I can live with that.
